channel.title: Reading packet data from official servers
channel.description:
Hi guys,
How would I go about reading the packet data sent from the OSRS servers to my PC? Would be interesting to get the IDs of the songs etc.
Thanks

item.title: Reading packet data from official servers
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Of course, you could write a Wireshark filter that decodes them with a given seed…

EDIT: Or, whatever Wireshark calls that particular plugin type, I can’t keep up with their terminology. ‘Dissector’, probably.

Read full topic
item.source: Reading packet data from official servers

item.title: Reading packet data from official servers
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

The opcodes change with each ISAAC nextInt() return value. The server is able to decrypt the opcode because it also has an ISAAC cipher with the same seed. The arguments to the opcode (the song id or whatever it is) never changes within the same revision, but may be subject to change across revisions (historically it hasn’t happened often afaik).

Read full topic
item.source: Reading packet data from official servers

item.title: Reading packet data from official servers
item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

[quote=“Miss Silabsoft, post:8, topic:547767”][quote author=Ambokile link=topic=666673.msg4457917#msg4457917 date=1415975443]
Okay, I’m using Wireshark. I’ve isolated all the TCP packets to/from port 43594 but I can’t figure out how to isolate the ones that I want. Specifically, I want to find the music IDs - how would I do this?
[/quote]
realistically unless the song ids are in a recognizable order you won’t be able to use wireshark for this task. Because the client implements the Isaac cipher the packet op codes are always changing so unless you know that the song ids are in a specific order where you can just look for it in the packet payloads you would not be able to easy find it.[/quote]

Do they change every time they’re sent or for every client instance?

Read full topic
item.source: Reading packet data from official servers

item.title: Reading packet data from official servers
item.dc:creator: @Metho_D Method
item.description:
@Metho_D wrote:

t4:

Yeah, but isn’t the ISAAC seed generated client-side?

Yes, but it’s encrypted when sent over the network.

Read full topic
item.source: Reading packet data from official servers

item.title: Reading packet data from official servers
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4

item.title: Reading packet data from official servers
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

Ambokile:

Okay, I’m using Wireshark. I’ve isolated all the TCP packets to/from port 43594 but I can’t figure out how to isolate the ones that I want. Specifically, I want to find the music IDs - how would I do this?

realistically unless the song ids are in a recognizable order you won’t be able to use wireshark for this task. Because the client implements the Isaac cipher the packet op codes are always changing so unless you know that the song ids are in a specific order where you can just look for it in the packet payloads you would not be able to easy find it.

Read full topic
item.source: Reading packet data from official servers

item.title: Reading packet data from official servers
item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

[quote=“Ashi, post:6, topic:547767”][quote author=Ambokile link=topic=666673.msg4457926#msg4457926 date=1415980329]
I want to know which song Id is played when I click Autumn voyage for example
[/quote]
Waste of time. Just dump the id’s from the cache and search the song.[/quote]

I want to know for every song though. I can’t search through thousands of songs and compare them all.

Read full topic

item.title: Reading packet data from official servers
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

Ambokile:

Okay, I’m using Wireshark. I’ve isolated all the TCP packets to/from port 43594 but I can’t figure out how to isolate the ones that I want. Specifically, I want to find the music IDs - how would I do this?

Huh? The music Id’s are stored in the cache. Why do you want to find the packet that sends the Id?

Read full topic

item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

item.source: Reading packet data from official servers

item.title: Reading packet data from official servers
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

Set up a simple proxy that forwards all data to/from an application and records it. You can write your own (it’s a few hundred lines) or use wireshark.

Read full topic
